Award.AwardTitle: Upscaling and multilevel methods for three dimensional elasticity via element agglomeration
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the integration of recent theoretical and algorithmic advances in numerical models, which describe the behavior of elastic materials on multiple scales, exhibiting stochastic behavior. The project will include algorithmic design, convergence and complexity analysis, as well as issues that arise in the performance of the upscaling and multilevel algorithms in realistic simulations. The proposed research: (1) aids the development of new and robust methods for upscaling that provide reliable calculations and predictions in structural mechanics; (2) supports the migration of such methods into real-life scientific and engineering simulations; and (3) engages the broader scientific community through research and educational activities, highlighting the integrated approach in numerical modeling of elastic materials from adaptive discretizations to robust solvers and back.

The proposed research aims to improve understanding of the interplay between the techniques from differential geometry and topology, which lead to discretizations compatible with the geometric and topological structures inherited from the physical/mathematical model. Based on this, the PIs plan to develop agglomeration methods that offer provable optimal algorithm performance. The novel efficient and accurate upscaling techniques for elasticity problems have potential applications in material sciences and geosciences. In addition, accurate coarse discretizations yield efficient multilevel solvers for the linear systems coming from corresponding discretizations of linear elasticity. Such solvers enable simulations with finer spatial resolution and/or reduce the necessary computational resources for such simulations. Finally, the design of upscaling techniques has many similarities with the design of discretizations in general. The success of the project will facilitate accurate discretization schemes and robust solvers for linear elasticity equations based on element agglomeration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on the integration of recent theoretical and algorithmic advances in numerical models on multiple scales.  The research objectives include algorithmic design, convergence and complexity analysis, as well as issues that arise in the performance of the upscaling and coarsening algorithms for discrete systems such as these corresponding to discretized partial differential equations with heterogeneous coefficients.

The research improves the understanding of the interplay between the general approaches offered by topological techniques in the upscaling of general graphs/networks and the geometrical structures inherited from the underlying physical/mathematical model under consideration.The project focuses on agglomeration/coarsening methods that offer provable optimal algorithm performance. These findings also yield efficient multilevel solvers for the linear systems coming from discretizations of partial differential equations as well as other discrete systems. They enable simulations with finer resolution by providing the tools to reduce the necessary computational resources for such simulations.

In the core of the research is a unified framework and theory that can be used to derive and analyze different multilevel and upscaling methods in a coherent manner. Optimal coarse spaces are identified by solving constrained minimization problems and is demonstrated that coarse spaces of most existing upscaling methods can be viewed as approximate solutions of such minimization problems. A basic tool in this is a new estimate on the asymptotic behavior of eigenvalues of discretized elliptic boundary values problems and a unified framework for the design and analysis of two-level (two-scale) methods. Techniques are developed for constructing directly a basis for locally optimal or quasi-optimal coarse space, such as the space of constant vectors for standard discretizations of scalar elliptic partial differential equations.

Another aspect of this project is on providing a posteriori error estimators for aggregation based coarsening/upscaling. This leads to generalizations of the hyper-circle error estimators (commonly used in the finite element methods) to error estimators on graphs/networks which are able to assess the quality of a given aggregation and reshape it to obtain an optimal coarse space.  These studies result in novel approaches in the construction of (quasi-)optimal coarse spaces and the corresponding theoretical results apply to a large pool of methods, including: the standard geometric upscaling (coarsening) methods, classical upscaling methods, energy-minimization coarsening, aggregation/agglomeration and spectral coarsening.

The project also has contributed to the study of energy laws for discretized partial differential equations. A question that is addressed in this aspect of the research is: How accurately a finite-element formulation adheres to the underlying energy law associated with the physical system? In the focus are the first-order system least-squares discretizations of time-dependent partial differential equations and an abstract framework is developed for showing estimates on the validity of discrete energy laws. The theory is applicable to a variety of finite element discretizations of time dependent  partial differential equations, including space-time formulations.

In summary, this research: (1) aids the development of new and robust methods for upscaling that provide reliable calculations and predictions in analysis of discrete systems; (2) supports the migration of such methods into real-life scientific and engineering simulations; and (3) engages students and the broader scientific community in studying the adaptive upscaling and coarsening algorithms in numerical modeling of networks/graphs and discrete systems and the application of such techniques to structural mechanic sand poromechanics.  The novel efficient and accurate upscaling techniques also have potential applications in material sciences and geosciences.
